questions.q: What does HTML stand for?
questions.explanation: HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language. It is the standard markup language used to create and structure content on the web.

questions.q: Which protocol is used by web servers to serve documents?
questions.explanation: HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is the protocol used by web servers to transmit web pages and other resources to clients (browsers).

questions.q: What is the primary function of a web browser?
questions.explanation: A web browser's main function is to fetch content from web servers, render it visually, and allow users to navigate between different resources through hyperlinks.
options: To retrieve, present, and traverse information resources on the web

questions.q: What is the main difference between a URL and a URI?
questions.explanation: URL (Uniform Resource Locator) is a specific type of URI that includes the location and access method. URI (Uniform Resource Identifier) is a broader concept that can identify resources without necessarily specifying their location.
options: A URL specifies the location of a resource, while a URI can identify any type of resource.
A URI specifies the location of a resource, while a URL can identify any type of resource.
A URL is used for email, while a URI is used for web pages.
There is no difference between a URL and a URI.

questions.q: What is the purpose of a hyperlink in a web page?
questions.explanation: Hyperlinks (or links) allow users to navigate from one web page to another, creating the interconnected web of information that defines the World Wide Web.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of the World Wide Web (WWW)?
questions.explanation: The WWW was created to provide an information space where documents and resources are interconnected through hyperlinks, making information easily accessible and navigable.
options: To provide an information space where documents are interlinked via hyperlinks

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a web browser?
questions.explanation: Microsoft Word is a word processing application, not a web browser. Chrome, Firefox, and Safari are all web browsers used to access and display web content.

questions.q: What does the acronym "URL" stand for?
questions.explanation: URL stands for Uniform Resource Locator. It specifies the address of a resource on the internet, including the protocol, domain, and path.

questions.q: What is the role of a web server?
questions.explanation: A web server stores web content and responds to client requests by sending the requested resources (HTML pages, images, etc.) back to the client's browser.
options: To generate and transmit responses to client requests for web resources

questions.q: What is the main characteristic of Web 2.0?
questions.explanation: Web 2.0 represents a shift from static web pages to dynamic, interactive platforms that emphasize user-generated content, collaboration, and social media features.
options: User-generated content and dynamic web pages

questions.q: Which tag is used to define the title of an HTML document?
questions.explanation: The <title> tag defines the title of the HTML document, which appears in the browser's title bar or tab. It's placed within the <head> section.

questions.q: What is the correct HTML tag for the largest heading?
questions.explanation: The <h1> tag represents the largest and most important heading in HTML. Heading tags range from <h1> (largest) to <h6> (smallest).

questions.q: HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language.
questions.explanation: True. HTML is an acronym for Hyper Text Markup Language, which is the standard language for creating web pages.

questions.q: The World Wide Web (WWW) is an example of client/server computing.
questions.explanation: True. The WWW follows a client-server model where browsers (clients) request resources from web servers, which then respond with the requested content.

questions.q: A web browser is used to create web pages.
questions.explanation: False. A web browser is used to view and navigate web pages, not create them. Web pages are created using text editors or specialized web development tools.

questions.q: A URL specifies the location of a resource on the internet.
questions.explanation: True. A URL (Uniform Resource Locator) provides the complete address needed to locate a specific resource on the internet.

questions.q: The primary purpose of a hyperlink is to display images.
questions.explanation: False. The primary purpose of a hyperlink is to navigate between web pages or different sections of content, not to display images.

questions.q: Web 2.0 is characterized by static web pages.
questions.explanation: False. Web 2.0 is characterized by dynamic, interactive web pages with user-generated content, not static pages. Static pages were more common in Web 1.0.

questions.q: A web server is responsible for generating and transmitting responses to client requests.
questions.explanation: True. Web servers process incoming HTTP requests from clients and generate appropriate responses, sending back the requested resources.

questions.q: The Internet and the World Wide Web (WWW) are the same thing.
questions.explanation: False. The Internet is the global network infrastructure, while the WWW is a service that runs on the Internet. The WWW is just one of many services available on the Internet.

questions.q: HTTP is the protocol used by web servers to serve documents.
questions.explanation: True. HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is the primary protocol used for transmitting web pages and other resources over the Internet.

questions.q: A web page can only contain text and no multimedia content.
questions.explanation: False. Modern web pages can contain various types of multimedia content including images, videos, audio, animations, and interactive elements.
